mcq_questions.title: The fluorescent label in QF-PCR is present on:
mcq_questions.feedback: Correct: by labelling the primers, different labels can be used, allowing for multiplexing

mcq_questions.title: How many copies of the original (diploid) template will be produced after 26 PCR reaction cycles?
choices: impossible to determine, as the reaction has moved out of the exponential phase
mcq_questions.feedback: Correct: 26 cycles is within the exponential phase, so the number of copies double for each cycle (number of cycles = n). Therefore 2n = the number of copies

mcq_questions.title: The problem with the original polymerase used for PCR was:
choices: it needed to be replaced after every cycle
mcq_questions.feedback: Correct: the high temperature used for denaturation would inactive the original polymerase

mcq_questions.title: The most common “livebirth” trisomy is:
mcq_questions.feedback: Correct: Down syndrome frequency is 1/700 live births

mcq_questions.title: QF-PCR is quantitative because
choices: it is based on limited cycle PCR
mcq_questions.feedback: Correct: the PCR reaction is halted during the exponential phase

mcq_questions.title: The term aneuploidy has the same meaning as:
mcq_questions.feedback: Correct: aneuploidy is changes in chromosome number not equal to an entire haploid set, so one extra or one missing is an example of aneuploidy

mcq_questions.title: If a chromosome marker has one peak, the most likely conclusion is:
choices: there is only one copy of the chromosome
the marker must be on the Y chromosome
there was an error in PCR amplification
mcq_questions.feedback: Correct: while all these options are possible, there are more autosomal chromosome markers tested, and you cannot assess peak area ratios with only 1 chromosome, so the peak is uninformative.

mcq_questions.title: An advantage of QF-PCR over conventional karyotyping is:
choices: QF-PCR does not require culturing of cells
QF-PCR can also detect balanced translocations
QF-PCR is performed using a commercial kit
mcq_questions.feedback: Correct: often culturing fails, so it is an advantage to use isolated DNA for PCR instead

mcq_questions.title: The most important step for PCR reaction specificity is:
mcq_questions.feedback: Correct: the temperature for annealing the primer is based on primer G/C content and should be set so the primer will only bind to specific unique sequences

mcq_questions.title: Which of the following is not a reason for performing QF-PCR?
choices: couple wants to know biological sex of fetus
mcq_questions.feedback: Correct: QF-PCR Is for prenatal assessment of aneuploidy risk, or for assessing for trisomy after pregnancy loss

mcq_questions.title: For TAF9L, the Chromosome 3 peak is
choices: sometimes 1/2 the area of the Chromosome X peak
sometimes the same area of the Chromosome X peak
mcq_questions.feedback: Correct: The Chromosome 3 product is invariant and always has a peak area equivalent to 2: if there are 2 copies of Chromosome X, the area of both peaks should be the same

mcq_questions.title: The normal peak area range is:
choices: there is no range, the value is always 1
mcq_questions.feedback: Correct: unless the 2 peaks for a marker are separated by more than 24bp, this is the ratio for a chromosomal copy number of 2 (i.e.normal)

PCR is based on viral replication
PCR uses magnesium as an enzyme cofactor
Chromosome 21 is assessed for prenatal and pregnancy loss cases
If one QF-PCR marker shows evidence of trisomy, that is sufficient evidence to conclude that a trisomy is present
The first step in PCR is the separation of DNA into single strands
If all Chromosome X markers have one peak, the patient must be a biological male
TAF9L amplifies loci on Chromosome 3 and Chromosome X
The ratio calculation for QF-PCR is based on peak height
Patau syndrome is associated with trisomy of chromosome 18
Klinefelter syndrome is a syndrome associated with sex chromosome aneuploidy
